awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Icy Road Forecast and Alert  Product Using  Road-Physics-Enhanced Weather Forecast Model and Remote Sensing Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to reduce risks on icy winter roads and thus enhance transportation safety. Snow-covered and icy roads result in fatalities and disruption of commercial transportation. Decision-makers in government and industry need real-time observations and reliable weather forecasts to support timely decisions to reduce risks associated with icy road conditions. This SBIR project aims to develop and commercialize an innovative technology to detect, forecast and alert end users to icy road conditions. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will integrate multi-satellite precipitation (liquid and frozen) and remote cloud sensing observations with a new physics-based road condition forecasting model to produce timely, secure, and efficient prediction of icy road conditions. Specifically, the proposed technology will use NOAA rainfall observations and NASA cloud observation services to assess surface temperature and water availability at a road surface, the two key parameters for ice formation on a road. In addition, a model incorporating a new surface energy budget and parameters to represent the physical and thermodynamic processes of road energy transportation will be developed to forecast icy road conditions up to 24 hours in advance. Furthermore, drone-mounted hyperspectral cameras using visible and near-infrared bands to detect ice on road surfaces will be developed. Collected black ice data from such cameras will be compared with the ground measurements from Road Weather Information Systems (RWIS) for validation. By combining these three new approaches, the technology is expected to reach an accuracy of approximately 85% for icy road forecasts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Icy road  is one of the primary reasons for winter road accidents. In addition, since anti-icing in pre-treatment is significantly cheaper than de-icing after ice occurrence, state and local transportation maintenance  managers are desired to know icy road forecast for  strategy of anti-ice/de-ice. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) disclosed that effective pretreatments for icy road typically require up to 75% less ice-melt material throughout the storm cycle compared to deicing after weather events, and consequently reducing costs and environmental impact. Our project developed icy road forecast and alert technology (IcyRoad) to forecast where ice would form on highways. This technology  reduces winter highway maintenance cost and enhance road safety, the two most critical duties for state Department of Transportation, our first customer sector.

The project product, IcyRaod web-app and mobile app,  implemented Internet-of-Things (IoT) technology, cloud computing, data analysis and visualization, and online database to solve a long-standing road ice forecast problem. It furthermore sheds light on in digital era, how to integrate new technologies with weather forecast to provide ad-hoc solutions in transportation sector.

Between February 2020 to May 2022, SpringGem Weather Information  worked on our NSF SBIR Phase 1 project entitled: “Icy Road Forecast and Alert  Product Using Road-Physics-Enhanced Weather Forecast Model and Remote Sensing Technologies” (NSF award number  1931673). Below outlines the primary outcomes of the project:

  1. Developed IcyRoad forecast for long-distance truck companies or drivers. The web-app is available at https://sg-weather.com/weather/ . The mobile app is published in Google Play and Apple store. This is a free app for community.
  2. Developed State-wide road ice forecast. Sample for Montana Department of Transportation.
  3. Developed IcyBridge for Georgia State Department of Transportation (GDOT)
  4. Conducted winter  field experiments using drone-based spectral sensor detecting technology on road ice and applied for US patent on the technology. Analysis of spectral reflectance measurements for asphalt, water, snow, melting snow, and vegetation (Aspen).
  5. Developed a demo-version of ground-based, solar panel powered, waterproof, portable IR sensor as part of Road Ice Detector to measure skin and air temperatures.

During this project, State Department of Transportations (Montana, Georgia) have worked with us to test use the road ice forecast. Industry partner from long-distance logistic company (ofoexpress.us) was also a customer segment testing our product. Encouraging feedbacks and insights have collected to reveal a clearly needed market in both industry and government.
